SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Morning, artist's workshop with dollhouses, miniature craftsman home revealed, bright sun

SCRIPT.LINE: An impressive room serving as an ARTIST’S WORKSHOP. It’s empty, but evidence of frantic creative activity abounds.
We PAN across the wall, crossing a series of meticulously hand-crafted DOLLHOUSES, mostly works in progress. As we drift past these unfinished dioramas, our trajectory becomes clearer...

We are moving in on an extraordinary sculpture of a beautiful, rustic CRAFTSMAN HOME, at 1:8 scale. Its front wall has been removed, exposing its rooms in graphic tableaux. This huge miniature is painstakingly detailed. It’s adorned with shrunken props/decorations (flashlights, pill bottles, shoes, etc.) and teensy furniture, all flawlessly rendered and distinguishable ONLY IN SIZE from their full-scale models.
We continue to pan/track across the miniature, edging CLOSER AND CLOSER as we drift along its tiny rooms. We finally arrive at a miniature replica of a TEENAGE BOY’S BEDROOM on the second floor.

We push towards this until the ROOM FILLS THE FRAME. The bright morning sun beams in through its window. It becomes apparent that a handsome, skinny BOY is sleeping in the bed. This is PETER GRAHAM (17).

We continue pushing gently in, remaining in a wide of the room (whose status as a miniature has now been confused). The door opens and STEVE GRAHAM (47) - tall, broad-shouldered, formal - pops his head in. He wears a black suit.
All right, Petey. Wake up time.
Peter stirs awake. Steve drops a folded-up BLACK SUIT AND TIE on the foot of the bed.
Here’s your suit.
MAX, the family’s golden retriever, shuffles happily in through the door.
Did your sister sleep in her room last night?

PATHS.CHOICE: Proceed to exterior of Graham House

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Same time, wide shot of the house identical to miniature, snow-covered landscape, parked car

SCRIPT.LINE: Wide on the house, revealing that it is IDENTICAL to the miniature that we saw in the workshop. The surrounding landscape is blanketed with SNOW.

Steve exits a back door to approach a very large TREEHOUSE. It is joined to a sturdy oak and hovers fifteen feet above the ground. We are subtly BOOMING DOWN from this wide view (as Steve begins to climb the tree) to arrive at a parked CAR - one of two family cars - in the foreground.
Sitting in the passenger seat is a bereaved woman (45). She wears all black, and is beautiful in a worn way. This is ANNIE GRAHAM, and she looks emotionally exhausted.
She wears a delicate NECKLACE bearing an ORNATE SIGIL, which she compulsively fingers.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Same time, interior of a treehouse, Charlie sleeping, drawing pad and shoebox nearby

SCRIPT.LINE: Steve pokes his head into the treehouse, where he finds: CHARLIE - a plump, androgynous fourteen year old girl - lying asleep on the floor. She wears a parka and pajama bottoms.
Beside her is a DRAWING PAD and an open SHOEBOX.
Oh my God, Charlie. Are you crazy?
Charlie wakes up, her nose pink and runny. When she notices Steve, she frantically reaches to SHUT the shoebox.
This is how you get pneumonia!
It’s okay.
Your mom’s in the car already, we’re late.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Morning, funeral chapel, open casket, large photo of Ellen Leigh, family in front row, other mourners

SCRIPT.LINE: A moderately attended FUNERAL. (A large group of MEN AND WOMEN observe from the back.)
Before the altar, an OPEN CASKET rests beside a blown up photo of the deceased ELLEN LEIGH, Annie’s 75 year old mother.
Annie, Steve, Charlie (now wearing an oversized black dress over her pajama bottoms) and Peter sit in the first row of chairs. They listen as a LARGE WOMAN (60s) speaks in remembrance of Ellen.
Ellen was a tough one. She didn't mince words, she abhorred the sentimental, and she was honest. And I know that's how she raised her children, Annie and Charles -
- may he rest in peace... To always be honest...
Half-listening (half-wincing), Annie’s attention is drawn to CHARLIE, who makes a quiet CLICKING noise with her tongue. This is a tic.
Suddenly, a bird FLAPS out from the rafters, startling the congregation.
The bird settles on a ceiling perch. It is a WHIPPOORWILL. It looks down, fixing its gaze on Annie. Annie looks very disturbed. Off-screen, the Large Woman continues.
MINUTES LATER Annie is now on the PLATFORM.
I just wanna say first...it’s very heartening to see so many strange new faces here today. I know my mom would be very touched (and probably a little suspicious) if she could see this turn-out, so...
Annie looks down to now read from a heavily edited loose-leaf page. This is her eulogy. (Not used to reading in public, she rarely looks up from the paper.)
My mother was an intensely secretive and private woman. She had private rituals, private friends, private anxieties... It honestly feels like a betrayal just to be standing here talking about her...
Annie pauses. She looks at the paragraph. It’s very long, and begins with the sentence “My mother was a chameleon.” She decides to skip ahead to the next paragraph.

She was a very difficult woman to read. If you ever thought you knew what was going on with her - and God forbid you tried to confront that...! (stops...pauses...skips ahead) ...But when her life was unpolluted, she could easily be the sweetest, warmest, most loving person in the world...
Charlie is DRAWING a weepy caricature of Annie at the platform. Steve watches this in the corner of his eye.
...She was also incredibly stubborn. Which maybe explains me.
Scattered, knowing laughter.
You could always count on her to always have the answer....
She stops short, eyes on the paper. The sentence would continue “and if she ever WAS mistaken - well, that was YOUR opinion and you were WRONG.”
Suddenly remorseful, Annie (off-book) asserts:
I did love her.
Charlie is still drawing. Steve closes the notepad. He points to Annie: “Listen to your mother.” Charlie grudgingly obliges.
She was especially strong about food. When I was a girl and I had to eat my veggies...
LATER The mourners have been invited up to view the deceased and say goodbye. Organ music plays as Annie, Steve, Peter (who doesn’t look) and Charlie shuffle by.

Charlie peers into the open casket to see her grandmother’s CORPSE. It wears a NECKLACE with a delicate SIGIL ORNAMENT (identical to Annie’s). The seams in the corpse’s make-up are eerily apparent and the lips are slightly twisted.
Unnerved, Charlie looks away. She meets eyes with a smiling MIDDLE-AGED BLONDE MAN standing in the queue behind her. He’s STARING at her - an overly sentimental look in his eyes.
Disturbed, Charlie averts her eyes.
Yeesh.
SECONDS LATER An older WOMAN arrives at the open casket. Her finger is dipped into a small bottle of OIL. She quickly and covertly STREAKS the oil along the corpse’s lips.
Seeing this, a following mourner squints with bewilderment.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Late afternoon, driving home, passing deer, family in car

SCRIPT.LINE: Steve is at the wheel, driving back home. Annie sits passenger, and Peter and Charlie sit in the back. They drive past a gathering of DEER.
How did you keep from screaming during Judy’s speech?
Ha. Well, if you could...!
Peter EYES the back of Annie’s head. She seems to grate on his nerves. Meanwhile, Charlie is back to making clicking noises with her tongue. She does this while unwrapping a CHOCOLATE BAR.
How about that bird flying in?
Yeah, that was weird.
That was too weird. The timing? It felt like it was my mom.
Steve nods, betraying a look of CONCERN. Annie self-consciously backtracks:
Not actually, obvi

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, inside a car, tense atmosphere

SCRIPT.LINE: ously. Just - it struck me.
Annie notices Charlie eating the chocolate bar.
Hey! Are there nuts in that?
No!
Better not be.
Annie returns her attention to the road. Steve lovingly takes her hand. She smiles at him.
Charlie, irritated, looks very tense.
I don’t like going back without grandma.
Well, sweetie...do you understand why we have to?
Charlie just tenses up, eyes narrowing onto the floor.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Evening, unlit house foyer, snow tracked in

SCRIPT.LINE: The house is unlit and seemingly vacant.
Off-screen, we hear FEET SCURRYING and a DOOR CLOSING. Max, the golden retriever, BARKS in reaction to this.
A moment later, the front door opens and the Graham family enters. They stamp the snow off their boots and remove their coats.
Max runs up, desperate to greet them. Steve bends down to happily receive him.
Charlie moves toward the stairs, still wearing her boots.
Hey hey -- shoes off.
Charlie pulls off her boots. She and Peter start separately up the stairs. Steve, looking down, notices dried FOOT-PRINTS around the foyer.
See? What’s with all these footprints? I’m tired of reminding everybody.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Evening, cluttered artist's workshop, miniature hospice model

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie is at her work desk. It’s a mess of paints, props, wood pieces, etc. She wears magnifying eye-glasses as she carefully paints eyes onto a SMALL DOCTOR FIGURINE for a MINIATURE HOSPICE. A figurine of an old woman - presumably Annie’s mother - lies in a miniature hospital bed.
Steve enters, disrupting Annie’s focus.
How’s it going?
Just working.
Steve casually rests a glass of water and a PILL on the table. She downs it without question.
Still toiling on the hospice?
Between that and the pre-school.
There is a half-finished MINIATURE PRE-SCHOOL in the corner.
How far are we now? Seven months?
Six and a half.
Yow. Comin’ up.
Her eyes widen with stress.
Any title ideas yet?

Annie grabs her laptop and pulls up a PDF for a poster promoting an upcoming EXHIBITION of her artwork. It features a photo of a magnificent living room miniature. Below this are the words “TITLE HERE” in bold, followed by “The Work of Annie Leigh.”
This is the photo they wanna use.
Ooh, I love that one.
The gallery owner keeps suggesting Your Life in Miniature for the title.
What do you think of that?
Annie looks at him, incredulous.
No good?
It’s horrible!
Yeah. A little trite.
A lot trite! Are you kidding? She won’t stop suggesting it!
Steve looks to a stack of LARGE MOVING BOXES in the corner. They’re marked “Mom’s Things” in Annie’s handwriting.
You want me to put that stuff in the attic?
...Yeah. Maybe not just yet.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, messy teenager's room, guitar, muted TV

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter sits up in bed, holding a guitar. He improvises a clunky tune as a muted TV plays cartoons. His eyes are on the TV.
The door cracks open and Steve pokes his head in.
Goodnight, kiddo.
‘Night, dad.
...What you playing?
Just plucking random strings.
You feeling okay about everything?
Yeah. Fine.
Little sad?
Peter shrugs again. He clearly wasn’t fond of Ellen.
Yeah. I know.
Okay, buddy. Love you.
Steve KISSES in Peter’s direction. Peter kisses back. Steve walks off, leaving the door open.
A moment later, Annie walks up to the doorway, still wearing her magnifying eye-glasses. She’s holding a prop in one hand, a fine paintbrush in the other.
‘Night sweetheart.
Goodnight. I’m sorry about your mom.
Thank you. I’m sorry about your grandma.
...Thank you.
Annie smiles, hesitates, and walks off. There’s a very loaded tension between these two.
After Annie is gone, Peter climbs out of bed to shut the door. He LOCKS it.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, artist's room, drawings on walls, handmade manikins

SCRIPT.LINE: Charlie’s room is that of a young artist. The walls are covered in drawings, and the desks and other surfaces are littered with different HANDMADE HUMAN MANIKINS and SMALL STATUES (all made of disparate parts - mostly found objects).
Annie sits on the edge of Charlie’s bed. Charlie is under the covers. Annie has opened Charlie’s drawing pad to see a CARICATURE of Annie’s mother’s corpse in its casket.
That’s grandma?
I dunno.
You know you were her favorite?
No I wasn’t.
Oh yes you absolutely were! Even when you were a little baby, she wouldn’t let me feed you because she needed to feed you. It drove me crazy.
She said I was supposed to be a boy.
Annie knows this. She hesitates, wanting to say the right thing.
How do you feel about that?
Charlie shrugs.
You know I was a tomboy growing up? I hated dresses and dolls and pink.
Charlie’s heard this before. She has tensed up.
Who’s gonna take care of me?
Ummm, excuse me? You don’t think I’m gonna take care of you?!
But when you die...
...Then dad will take care of you. Or Peter.
Charlie’s head remains turned. Discouraged, Annie turns back the page of the drawing pad. She now sees the caricature of her, crying at the pulpit.
Who’s this one?
No answer. Annie takes it personally, but pretends not to.
She closes the book with a smile.
You never even cried as a baby - you know that? Not even when you were born.
Charlie ignores this.
Did you feel like you wanted to cry today?
Without looking at Annie, Charlie shrugs a tense “I don’t know.”
Do you think that might feel like a relief?
Charlie remains miles away.

Annie looks up to notice that a difficult-to-read WORD (looks like “Satony”) has been CARVED into the wall behind Charlie’s bed. Annie pauses, lets it go, and then bends down to KISS Charlie’s forehead.
Goodnight, sweetie.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, peaceful snowfall outside, eerie darkness within

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie enters. Outside the window: peaceful snowfall.
Annie hesitates before walking over to the box labeled “Mom’s Things.” She reluctantly opens it...

The box is filled with bottled oils and herbs. At the top of the box is a PHOTO ALBUM titled “Memories.” Annie opens it to sift through photos of her mother. She lays the album back into the box, and then notices a stack of worn HARDBACKS. She pulls one out. “NOTES ON SPIRITUALISM.”
This calls back unwelcome memories. Annie dumps the book back into the box, and PUSHES the box away.
Annie walks to the door and flips off the light, leaving the room in darkness (save for the moonlight). She’s about to leave, but something makes her FREEZE.
Standing motionless in a dark corner (almost too dark to make out) is ANNIE’S MOTHER, ELLEN - wearing the same outfit as the funeral. She’s staring at Annie. SMILING.
Annie, nearly paralyzed with fear, reaches for the light switch. Without looking away, she turns the light back ON.
Her mother is gone.
Annie remains motionless.
Mom?
Annie’s eyes are now drawn to...

A dusty older MINIATURE in the corner. It's a replica of Annie's bedroom. A figurine of Annie (in her early thirties) BREASTFEEDS a baby. Standing beside her is a figurine of an OLDER WOMAN (Annie’s mother) holding her naked BREAST out of her nightgown. She leans over, offering it to the baby.
Competing with Annie.
Troubled by this, Annie walks briskly to the miniature and TURNS it away. It’s now facing the wall as Annie returns to the door, flicks off the light, and leaves.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, quiet bedroom, Annie climbing into bed

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie climbs into bed with Steve.
I just scared myse

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, cozy bedroom, bedside lamp

SCRIPT.LINE: Oh no. With what?
Annie pauses. Thinks about telling him. Steve looks interested/slightly worried. Annie thinks better of it.
She smiles “nah.”
Goodnight.
Annie turns off the bedside lamp and gives Steve a blunt kiss.
Mm, mm - no you don’t.
He extends the kiss, making it last. Then:
Goodnight.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Next morning, blackboard with rules, students taking quiz

SCRIPT.LINE: Charlie’s “special needs” class.
Scrawled on the blackboard are the words “Quiet means Silence!” and all the students are indeed silent as they take a quiz.

The Teacher (40s) walks along the rows of desks, overlooking the quiz-takers. He comes to Charlie, whose quiz is upside-down. In her lap, she is assembling a small manikin’s body with disparate found objects (wood, metal, cardboard, etc).
Are you done?
What? ...Almost.
So maybe we finish the toy after the quiz? What do you think?
...Okay.
The teacher gently turns the quiz right-side-up. Charlie is extremely tense through this.
Suddenly a pigeon flies into the window, slamming its head. The impact breaks its neck.
The classroom erupts with excitement - “Oh my God!” “Did you see that?!” - but not Charlie. She stares tensely at her desk, still disturbed by the teacher’s interference.
Charlie’s eyes scan up. They alight on a pair of scissors on the Teacher’s desk.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, chalkboard with Greek tragedy themes, students discussing

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter’s English class. The chalkboard reads: "Themes - Escaping Fate. - Relationship between knowledge and responsibility. - 'No man considered fortunate until he is dead.'"
The teacher, Mr. Davies (30s), tries to facilitate a group discussion. He holds a copy of Sophocles’ The Women of Trachis.
So if we're going by the rule that a hero is undone by his fatal flaw, what was Heracles’ flaw?
Fucking his mom.
Some laughter from the class.
Wrong play, Sam. And watch your language.
Meanwhile, Peter is being hypnotized by Bridget (17), the attractive girl sitting in front of him. Peter’s rapt attention is glued to the butt of her jeans.
Come on, guys: What was Heracles’ flaw?
Arrogance.
This piques Peter’s interest.
Okay - why?
Because he literally refuses to look at all the signs that are being literally handed to him the entire play.
Peter’s in love.
Okay, interesting! So he thinks he has control.
Plus he fucked his mom.
More laughs.
That’s two strikes, Sam. But also, don’t forget: Sophocles writes it so the oracle is unconditional. Meaning Heracles never had any choice. Right?
Peter’s smartphone vibrates with a text.
So, does this make it more tragic or less tragic than if he did have a choice?
Less!
Peter checks his text. It’s from Brendan. It reads: “Wanna smoke a bowl at break?” This came from the Boy behind him.
Okay: Why?
Because!
Mr. Davies turns to Peter, who’s now composing a text in his lap.
Care to weigh in, Peter?
Peter looks up, a deer in headlights.
About which part?
Is it more tragic if it’s inevitable than if the characters had agency?
Peter is not following.
Yes?
Why?
...Because he had sex with his mom?
Dead air. Mr. Davies gives Peter an unencouraging look.
Another student picks up the slack:

I think it's more tragic - because if it’s all just inevitable, that means the characters have no hope and that they never had hope, because they’re just like pawns in this horrible, hopeless machine.
Peter has now noticed Bridget looking at him. She gives him a sardonic “nice try” smile. Peter smiles back, embarrassed. She turns away. Peter’s smile turns to a longing stare.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, recess, dead pigeon in bushes

SCRIPT.LINE: Recess.
The dead pigeon lies pathetically in the bushes below Charlie’s classroom window.

Charlie stands nearby, staring at the pigeon. After some time, she fishes a pair of scissors from her parka pocket. (These are the scissors from her teacher’s desk.) Charlie extends the scissors, fits the blades around the pigeon’s neck, and snips off its head.
Charlie quickly pockets the pigeon head, and looks up to notice:
An Older Woman (60s) sitting on a bench, just beyond the schoolyard fence. She is gazing at Charlie, sentimental.
Charlie gawks at the woman, unnerved. Without breaking eye contact, she pulls a chocolate bar from her pocket.
In the b.g., Peter walks past, joined by Brendan. Seeing the chocolate, Peter casually asserts:
No nuts, Charlie.
This makes Charlie freeze up with tension.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Afternoon, sparsely decorated office, Steve and patient in chairs

SCRIPT.LINE: Steve’s office is large and sparsely decorated.
Steve sits in a leather chair with a notepad resting on his lap. Sitting opposite him is an extremely agitated, depressed female Patient (40s). Steve studies her non-judgmentally.
And how’s the anger?
Same. I just don’t care as much.
So not as consuming?
It’s just as consuming, I just don’t care as much.
Steve, stifling frustration, affects superhuman patience.
And how’s your appetite been? With the Serafem...versus the Lexapro.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, Annie at Graham house model, laptop open

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie’s laptop is open to a website: “Discernment of Presumed Apparitions.”
Annie, sitting at the Graham house model, is carefully painting a miniature laptop, featuring the very same website.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, open door to hallway, mostly empty room with bed and photos

SCRIPT.LINE: We are looking through the open door into the hall.
Hello!
Hi!
Annie steps out into the hall and walks past the doorway. A moment later, we hear her footsteps freeze. She soon returns into view, now looking very unsettled. She stares past us, into the room...

Annie’s POV: The room is mostly empty, save for the bed (stripped of sheets), a bookshelf, and various framed photos featuring members of the family. One photo: a portrait of Annie and her mother, standing side by side. There is also a large triangle (pointed northwest) that has been carved violently into the floorboards.
Annie doesn’t react to the triangle. It was clearly already there.
Annie leaves.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Moments later, Steve on couch watching news, Annie enters

SCRIPT.LINE: Steve sits on the couch, having just turned on the news. He’s still wearing his coat.
Annie enters.
Were you in my mom’s room?
What? No.
The door was open.
Steve makes a “hmm” face.
The front door is heard opening, and Annie goes to the foyer, where Peter and Charlie are entering.
Hey guys. How was school?
Okay.
Did either of you go into Grandma’s room recently?
They both squint. “Why would we go in there?”
I don’t think you need to worry about me ever being in that room.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Evening, dark hallway, door to mother's room

SCRIPT.LINE: Steve is at Annie’s Mother’s door. He locks it (by key) from the outside.
Sorry. I know it’s irrational.
Not at all.
Illustrating that it’s locked, Steve tries turning the knob.
Thank you.
She kisses Steve, feeling dopey.
Peter walks up to them, holding the phone.
Dad? It’s the cemetery.
About what?
I’ll see. Hi... Yeah...
Steve walks down the hall to create distance between him and Annie. Now irked, Annie walks off.
Okay.... And what does “desecrated” mean? What? It's only been a week.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, interior of a home, slightly dim

SCRIPT.LINE: The hall, now wearing a coat.
Steve nervously accelerates:
Okay. All right. Can I actually call you back?... Okay, fine.
Steve hangs up.
I’m gonna go see a movie.
Okay. Right now?
I think I just need to get out of the house for a second.
...Want me to join?
I think I might just need like an hour to myself. I’m really tense.
Okay...great. I think you should.
Annie smiles “thanks.”
Do you know where Charlie is?
Where else?
Annie knows what that means. She immediately looks frustrated.
Let it go. It’s wasted energy.
It’s below 30 outside! So let her catch a cold.
Maybe she needs one.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Evening, interior of a treehouse, gruesome animal heads, flies buzzing

SCRIPT.LINE: Charlie sits in her treehouse. She lays the severed pigeon head into her SHOEBOX. Inside this box are three other SEVERED ANIMAL HEADS. One belongs to a rabbit, one to a rat, one to a squirrel. (The heads are in different stages of decomposition; flies buzz about.)
Down below, Annie is heard:
Charlie?
Charlie shuts the box, SHOVES it into a corner, and peers down to see ANNIE at the tree’s base.
Come on, sweetie. It’s freezing out here.
No response from Charlie. Annie doesn’t push it.
Okay, well, I’m running out for a sec. Is there anything I can bring you back?
Why??

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, inside a car, parked in a high school lot

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie idles into the parking lot of a Catholic high school.
She parks, turns off the engine, and sits in silence for a moment. Bracing herself.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, high school gym, chairs in a circle, various mourners

SCRIPT.LINE: A SUPPORT GROUP held in the high school’s gymnasium. A sign on an easel reads “LOSING A LOVED ONE, Grief Recovery.” The session hasn’t yet started. Twenty empty chairs form a CIRCLE in the space’s center.
Mourners of varying affect are scattered about, mingling.
Annie ENTERS, very ill-at-ease.
THIRTY MINUTES LATER
All the chairs are now filled. A middle-aged MEXICAN WOMAN speaks (in Spanish) through coursing tears. A YOUNG MAN translates for her as the rest of the group listens.
Sometimes I even get so relieved... Because he was in so much pain, and by the end he just hated himself. Always saying “I’m a burden, I’m a burden, I’m a burden”...
Annie’s eyes are wide. She’s empathizing with this, but it seems to also be agitating her.
FIVE MINUTES LATER
The GROUP LEADER addresses the group.
We’ve set aside some time for any newcomers who might like to speak...
Silence.
So, anybody new - if it’s your first or second time with us: the floor is open.
Annie looks very torn. She starts to lift up her hand, but stops short.
Yes?
Annie looks panicked.
Would you like to...?
...Maybe not.
Okay. No pressure.
Annie nods, takes a long moment, and then forces herself:
My name’s Annie.
Hi Annie.
Annie strains a smile. She continues tensely, as if against her will:

My mom died a week ago, so I’m just here for - trying it. I have a lot of resistance to things like this, but I went to these a couple years ago - I was pressured to come - but it did help, so... My mom was old and she wasn’t all together at the end - and we were pretty much estranged before that - so it wasn’t a huge blow. But I did love her. And she didn’t have an easy life... She had D.I.D., which became extreme in the last year, and dementia...! My dad died of starvation when I was a baby. He had psychotic depression and he starved himself. Which I’m sure was as pleasant as it sounds. And then my older brother - he was schizophrenic - and when he was sixteen, he hanged himself in my mom’s bedroom.
Of course his suicide note blamed her. Accusing her of putting people inside of him. So that was my mom’s life!
Annie looks to the group. They allow her time to continue. She reluctantly proceeds.

...She finally lived in our house at the end. Before hospice. We weren’t talking before that -- or we were and then we weren’t and then we were - she was completely manipulative - until finally my husband enforced a No Contact rule, which lasted until I was pregnant with my daughter. I didn't let her near me when I had my first - my son - which is why I gave her my daughter, who she immediately stabbed her hooks into. And of course I felt guilty again when she got sick... Not that she was even my mom at the end. And not that she ever felt guilty. About anything.
Annie has worked herself up. A charged pause as she calms back down.
And I don’t wanna put any more stress on my family. Not even sure if they could give me that support.
She gets stuck here. Tears begin to well. She struggles to squeeze out the following:
It just all sometimes feels ruined. And then I realize I'm to blame. Or not that I'm to blame, but that I'm...blamed.
Beat.
And what do you think you feel blamed for?
Annie looks to the leader. Pauses.
I apparently acted a certain way - according to them - I did things, in my sleep, a couple years ago. Or almost did them...
Annie looks like she’s going to continue, but then she abruptly cuts herself off. That’s it.
We reveal the mystified GROUP. They struggle to remain sympathetic, despite their confusion.
So anyway. Everything’s disappointing. So here I am.
She forces a laugh, but also cries a bit. She wipes away the tears and makes an embarrassed “bah” face. She then motions to the group: “Who’s next?”

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, interior, dimly lit hallway, stairs, Annie looking depleted

SCRIPT.LINE: At the end of the hall, a very depleted Annie has just finished scaling the stairs.
In the f.g., Peter’s door eases shut.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, teenager's messy room, laptop open, dim lighting

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter’s laptop is open. The browser displays BRIDGET’S FACEBOOK PAGE. (Peter has been going through her photos.) Behind that, another page displays “POPULAR CAREER INTERESTS.”
Peter walks from the door (which he just closed) to his desk.
He grabs a small water pipe, packed with marijuana, and walks to the window.
As Peter takes a hit from his pipe, his smartphone vibrates with a TEXT. He checks it.
From “Brendan”: Holy shit. Huge party tomorrow at Aaron’s house. Bring your dick!

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, wide shot of a house, subtle smoke from a window

SCRIPT.LINE: A WIDE of the house. In the foreground seems to be someone’s SHOULDER.
Pot smoke is blown out of Peter’s window, followed by a brief fit of COUGHING.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, interior, snowing outside, disturbing art supplies, manikin, pigeon head

SCRIPT.LINE: Charlie, dressed in her pajamas and munching on M&Ms, sits at her desk. She’s is finishing the torso for another small human manikin. The limbs are made of different scraps.

To the side of Charlie’s sculpture-in-progress is the SEVERED PIGEON HEAD. Beside that is Charlie’s drawing pad, open to an unfinished STILL LIFE of the pigeon head. And on the far side of the desk: a crude, bare stage for an unfinished DIORAMA.
As she works, Charlie makes the CLICKING SOUND with her tongue.
Suddenly, a GLINT of light sweeps the room in a quick FLASH.
Charlie ceases drawing. Her clicking STOPS. Disturbed by the flash, she raises her head and HOLDS. Listening for something?
After a beat, Charlie rises from her seat and walks to the WINDOW. It’s snowing outside. She stands there for a long time, her back to us. She’s STARING at something...

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, interior, modern kitchen, Annie preparing dinner

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie is preparing dinner. Her smartphone DINGS with an INCOMING EMAIL. It’s from The Asher Gallery. She opens it. It reads:
Hi Annie! Don't want to bother you, but we’d love to see where we are (progress-wise). Could you possibly send us pics of

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Vast wooded area, still snowing, distant fire crackling

SCRIPT.LINE: The vast WOODED AREA behind the Graham house. It is still snowing.
Charlie, wearing regular shoes and no coat (and still dressed in her pajamas), takes wide steps as she slogs through the snow.
She gazes listlessly ahead, as if in a TRANCE. She’s being drawn toward something. Like she’s sleepwalking with open eyes.
Max, the family dog, follows happily behind. A FIRE is heard crackling in the distance. Is this what she’s walking toward?
We cut to an EXTREME HIGH ANGLE - almost bird’s eye. This reveals that Charlie seems to be following a FRESH PATH OF FOOTPRINTS (source unknown) leading off-screen.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Annie working intensely on miniatures, anxious

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie is now WORKING INTENSELY on one of her miniatures. She looks very anxious.
Peter appears at the door.
Hey, uh...
Annie looks up, visibly annoyed by the disturbance.
...do you think I could borrow one of the cars tonight?
Why? Where are you going?
Oh, just like a school BBQ thing.
Annie continue working on the miniature, breaking intermittently as they speak:
Does that mean you’re not having dinner with us?
Oh, no, I was still gonna eat here.
Well - you can eat there if you want.
No, I’ll eat here.
Annie pauses. Her mind is not quite on this right now. She takes a moment (pulling herself from her work) to assess the questions that need to be asked.
No drinking?
Nobody’s old enough to even get drinks if they wanted to.
Well, that’s a crock. I’m just asking if you’re drinking.
Well, I just answered no.
Annie looks him hard in the eye before accepting that.
...You gonna take your sister?
Uh - does she want to go?
Uh - have you asked her?

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Inside the Graham house, Peter checking Charlie's room

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter goes to Charlie’s room. She’s not there.
Charlie?!

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Annie's workshop, Annie frustrated

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter returns to the workshop.
She’s not in the house.
Frustrated, Annie throws down her paintbrush:
What? Yes she is.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Snowy woods, distant burning torches and a mysterious figure

SCRIPT.LINE: Charlie is still walking through the snow. She sees in the DISTANCE, almost too far away to distinguish...

A ring of BURNING TORCHES has been set up. Within this ring, an OLD WOMAN’S INANIMATE BODY (dead?) stands erect - tied to a pole, with her arms strapped to outstretched planks. The body is dressed in FINE WHITE SILK. It looks like Ellen Leigh (Charlie’s grandmother), but it’s too far away to quite tell.
Charlie squints at this, barely reacting, when--
CHARLIE!
Charlie looks to ANNIE, who is running in her direction.
Charlie steps toward Annie.
What are you doing?! It’s below freezing out here!
Annie arrives at Charlie, not seeing the distant torches. She seizes Charlie’s arm and starts leading her back to the house.
Are you an idiot? You can’t just roam around - no coat, no boots!
Charlie YANKS her arm away from Annie.
Oh - what? You’re angry with me?
Annie GRABS Charlie’s arm and PULLS her back toward the house.
I want grandma.
Yeah. That makes one of us.

PATHS.CHOICE: Annie takes Charlie back to the house

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Inside the house, Annie stamping snow off boots

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie and Charlie return. Annie aggressively stamps the snow off her boots.
You’re going to this party with your brother.
What party?
A school hang-out with other kids.
That’s okay.
No, it’s not okay. You’re going.
Why?
Because it’ll be fun. You can hang out.
With who?
With your brother! With other kids!
Peter has stepped into the hall. He nods, as if to say “yeah, come along,” but his eyes are very uninviting.
...Fine.
Great. You’re going.
She’s going with you.
Great.
And that really means no drinking.
Yeah: I really wasn’t going to.

PATHS.CHOICE: The siblings prepare to leave for the party

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Evening, full moon glowing pale-blue over a lonely highway

SCRIPT.LINE: The sun has set. A FULL MOON glows pale-blue over a lonely highway.
The Graham family car (the green one) FLASHES past.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, Peter driving, Charlie in back, passing a telephone pole

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter is tense at the wheel. He drives the speed limit.
Peter’s eyes drift to the REAR VIEW MIRROR... Charlie, sitting in the back, CLICKS her tongue.
Peter’s eyes narrow resentfully back onto the road.

The car passes a TELEPHONE POLE. Just an average telephone pole. But we HOLD on it for a second longer than feels necessary. Hyper-attentive viewers might notice that a small SIGIL has been carved into it.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Large, modern house, windows glimpsing a big party

SCRIPT.LINE: A large, modern house. The windows feature glimpses of a big party, filled with circulating kids.
Peter and Charlie walk up the driveway. Charlie, suddenly very nervous, starts slowing down.
Maybe I don’t have to go in...
Peter stops.
Why? What’s wrong?
It’s okay. I can just stay out here.
Charlie, you’re the one who wanted to come.
So you just go. I’ll be out here.
Charlie: If you don’t come in, I have to take you back home, and that’ll take an hour.

PATHS.CHOICE: Peter convinces Charlie to enter the party

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Bustling house, kitchen with girls, living room with Peter and Charlie

SCRIPT.LINE: The house is bustling. In the KITCHEN, two girls pull a CAKE from the oven. Another girl (working on the frosting) CHOPS up loads of WALNUTS on a chopping board.
ECU of the nuts being brutalized.
In the LIVING ROOM, Peter stands awkwardly with Charlie.
Charlie grips her drawing pad.
AARON (17), a preppy-looking kid, walks suspiciously over to Peter. This is Aaron’s house.
Hey.
Hey. Nice house.
How did you hear about this?
Text.
Aaron nods, annoyed. He takes an aggressive sip of his drink.
Peter is uncomfortable.
Your parents are out of town?
Peter suddenly spots BRIDGET across the room. She sits on the COUCH, obviously inebriated, nursing a beer. Completely alone.
You didn’t bring beers or anything, did you?
Peter turns back to Aaron, very impatient now.
What? No. I actually have to go to the bathroom.
Aaron nods “yeah, whatever.” Peter, already backing away, turns to Charlie.
Stay here one second, okay? I’m just going to the bathroom.
Peter starts walking. Charlie immediately follows. Peter feigns a trajectory toward the bathroom just behind Bridget.
As he walks, he pretends to notice her. He affects a surprised face.
Whoa, hey! What’s up?
Oh. Hey.
Peter steps toward her. A brief pause.
How’s the party?
Why? You wanna know if you should come?
Uh - yeah. What do you think?
Whatever.
Okay, maybe I will.
Okay, I’ll see you here.
Another awkward pause.
Do you happen to smoke at all?
Smoke what?
Peter pinches into his pocket. He reveals the top of a rolled-up BAG OF MARIJUANA.
Is that tobacco or weed?
Really awesome weed.
Bridget considers, and then:
I could get more high.
She stands up.
The other room has a bong.
Bridget gestures for him to follow her. Peter starts to walk, but then notices Charlie following him.
Hey. You wanna stay out here for a second?
Nope.
Charlie: please: Only for two minutes and then we can hang out. You can draw.
Bridget is already at the DOOR to the other room. She looks expectantly at Peter, who turns again (desperately) to Charlie.
Please Charlie, I promise. I just need to do something really quick.
Peter then SEES something.
Oh shit. Look:
He’s pointing at the KITCHEN. The t

PATHS.CHOICE: Peter reacts to something in the kitchen

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Teenage party, chocolate cake being served, casual setting

SCRIPT.LINE: teen girls are now cutting into a fresh CHOCOLATE CAKE. They hand slices around.
They’re giving out chocolate cake.
Not to everyone.
Yes they are. It’s a party.
I don’t know anyone.
Nobody does. Just walk over, stand there, and they’ll give you one.
Peter starts walking off, still facing Charlie:
You should hurry, they’re gonna run out, I’ll be right back! Hurry!
Peter rushes over to Bridget as she OPENS the door to the other room. Charlie looks nervously to the kitchen.

PATHS.CHOICE: Peter goes to the other room, Charlie considers cake

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Boys watching videos on a tablet, Bridget enters

SCRIPT.LINE: Two BOYS - one Hispanic and one blonde - are in the room, watching videos on a tablet. Bridget enters, addressing them:
Hey guys, Peter has weed.
The boys turn to Peter. Peter immediately deflates.
Sativa or indica?

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Girls handing out slices of chocolate cake

SCRIPT.LINE: Charlie steps into the doorway. Extremely shy. Her eyes are magnetized to the CHOCOLATE CAKE as the girls continue handing out slices.
One GIRL notices Charlie’s fixed eyes. She warmly offers Charlie a slice. Charlie accepts without looking her in the eye.
Thanks.
Charlie turns, digging into the cake. (Nuts are visibly a key ingredient.)

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Peter sitting on bed, packing a bong, cell phone vibrating

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter sits on the bed, beside Bridget. He packs marijuana into the bowl of a large bong.
That was your sister, right?
Yeah. Charlie.
Peter’s cell phone VIBRATES.
Is your sister hot?
Peter checks the cell. It’s ANNIE calling. Tense, he tucks the phone back into his pocket.
I actually saw her drawing me last week.
Oh yeah?
Yeah, she made me look crazy.
That’s Charlie.
Peter’s phone VIBRATES again. A yellow “Message Waiting” light blinks. Annie has left a VOICEMAIL.

PATHS.CHOICE: Peter continues to ignore Annie's calls

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Charlie looking concerned, holding an empty plate, seeking water

SCRIPT.LINE: Charlie walks around, holding an empty plate, her lips covered in chocolate. She stops for a moment to SWALLOW. She pauses, then swallows again. She looks slightly concerned.
Charlie goes to a stack of RED CUPS and pulls one. She goes to the kitchen faucet and draws herself a cup of water.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Miniature of Graham house, Annie's mother figurine placed

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie is working on the miniature of the Graham house. She plants a freshly-painted FIGURINE of a ghostly old woman in a bathrobe (clearly Annie’s MOTHER) in the upstairs hall. The figurine looms outside the open door of the master bedroom replica, where figurines of Annie and Steve are asleep in bed.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Party in full swing, Charlie on couch, pink and inflamed cheeks

SCRIPT.LINE: The party is still in full swing.

Charlie has found her way onto the COUCH and is now assembling a small manikin from disparate parts (from her pocket). Her cheeks look pink and slightly INFLAMED. An allergic reaction to the cake? It looks like she’s on the verge of throwing up, but she keeps her concentration on the manikin.
A concerned BOY (16) approaches Charlie. Not recognizing that she’s a girl:
Hey dude, you okay? You want some water?
Charlie doesn’t even look up.
I’m okay.
You sure?
Mm-hmm.
The Boy hesitantly walks off. Charlie does NOT look good.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Peter taking a bong hit, Charlie opening the door, looking scared

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter is drawing an impressive bong hit.
The door is OPENED by Charlie.
Peter?
This is just as Peter finishes inhaling. He COUGHS up smoke.
Charlie!
Peter immediately hides the bong behind his legs and looks to Charlie, affecting casualness.
What’s up?
Charlie looks scared.
Are you okay?
It’s hard to breathe.
Charlie’s voice is cracked and strange.
What do you mean?
My tongue is getting bigger.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, distraught Peter pulling red-faced, bulging-eyed Charlie to car

SCRIPT.LINE: A distraught Peter pulls Charlie to the car. Charlie’s eyes bulge and her face is pitch-red. She seems UNABLE TO BREATHE.
Peter desperately opens the back door, guides Charlie in, slams the door, and runs to the driver side of the car.

PATHS.CHOICE: Peter drives Charlie to the hospital

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Speeding car on empty highway, Charlie gasping and gurgling in backseat

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter speeds down the empty HIGHWAY. In the back seat, Charlie GASPS and gurgles for breath. She KICKS at the door and GRASPS at her throat. Tears of pain stream down her face.
Peter ACCELERATES. Speeding from 60 MPH to 65.
You’re okay, Charlie! We’re going to the hospital!
Charlie frantically rolls down her window. Desperate for air.
Peter continues accelerating. 70 MPH.
Charlie forces her head through the BACK PASSENGER WINDOW. She GASPS for breath, but her throat is swollen shut. She can’t even scream.
Peter continues accelerating. 75 MPH.
Charlie sticks her squealing head even farther out the window.
Peter continues accelerating. 80... 85... But THEN--
A grisly DEER CARCASS, smeared across the road, appears in the car’s headlights.
Peter SWERVES out of the way.
CHARLIE’S HEAD, flailing out of the window, COLLIDES FACE-FIRST WITH A TELEPHONE POLE. The impact is so great that Charlie’s head is RIPPED OFF its shoulders.
The decapitated head SAILS silently in the car’s wake.
Peter STOMPS on the brakes. The car SQUEALS to an ear-splitting halt.
The frozen car chugs quietly. Suspended in time.
Peter sits motionless. Paralyzed. His eyes are fixed on the road in front of him.
In the SIDE-VEW MIRROR, the dead deer (thirty feet back) is faintly visible in the car’s brake lights. Bathed in red.
Peter doesn’t dare look back. His foot is jammed into the brake.
In the back seat, Charlie sits headless. A torso.
Peter’s EYES begin to stray toward the REAR-VIEW MIRROR, but they STOP before they get there. Peter can’t look.
Peter reaches for the rear-view mirror and subtly turns it AWAY.
The “Voicemail Waiting” light (from Peter’s cell) blinks through the fabric of his jeans pocket.
A long moment of silence, and then...
Peter’s foot slowly eases OFF the brake pedal.
The car begins to slowly idle forward.
Peter, eyes locked on the road ahead, allows the car to slowly pick up speed. His demeanor suggests that he’s in great denial. As if he’s saying to himself “it’s okay, nothing happened.”
The car drives onward. The headless torso rattles gently in the back seat.

PATHS.CHOICE: Peter drives home in a state of denial

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, car idling quietly into driveway, Peter exits in a dream state

SCRIPT.LINE: The car idles quietly into the driveway. It PARKS beside the other family car, but the engine continues humming.
The driver door opens, setting off the dull DING-DING-DING of the “door open/engine on” alarm. After a long pause, the engine is turned off. Peter steps out, as if in a dream state.
He walks stiffly away from the car and into the house.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Peter walking woodenly through the hall

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter stalks woodenly through the hall. He walks into his bedroom, leaving Annie and Steve to their sleep.
Peter climbs into bed, his door left open.

PATHS.CHOICE: Peter goes to bed, leaving the door open

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Morning, close-up on Peter's wide-open eyes, sounds from downstairs

SCRIPT.LINE: The next morning. CLOSE-UP on Peter’s face, turned halfway into his pillow. His eyes are wide open.
Downstairs, we hear Annie pulling on her coat.
I’m running out for some balsa wood. You want anything?
I’m good, baby. Drive safe.
Okay! Back in twenty!

The front door is heard opening and shutting. We then hear: Annie walking to the car... The car door opening... Annie beginning to climb in. And then... Silence. Followed by... A horrible SCREAM, shrill and almost inhuman-sounding, issues from outside. Peter’s eyes WIDEN.

Annie is heard staggering backwards and falling down, muttering (almost inaudibly) “No, no, no, no...” Downstairs (in the house) Steve is heard reacting and running to the front door. Before he makes it outside, Annie lets out another blood-curdling SHRIEK, which prompts a HARD CUT TO:

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Morning, Charlie's decapitated head resting by the side of the road

SCRIPT.LINE: CHARLIE’S HEAD rests by the side of the road. The nose is comple

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, storm raging outside, bedroom door cracked open

SCRIPT.LINE: The sound of THUNDER bridges our cut to:
A STORM rages outside.
Annie and Steve’s bedroom door is cracked open. We barely see ANNIE lying in bed, WEEPING and MOANING. Steve, sitting on the bed, consoles her. He tries to feed her a pill.
NO! I can't! I can't! I just wanna die!... I can't.
Steve rubs her head as she sinks into a more placid despair.
...It hurts too much. I just need to die.
And then more feelings come SURGING up. She MOANS an anguished moan.
We reveal PETER, standing paralyzed on the stairs, LISTENING. His mother’s cries shred at his nerves.
CHARLIE!!!

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, overcast, sad gathering of mourners

SCRIPT.LINE: An overcast day. A sad gathering of mourners. Annie, Peter and Steve stand lost among them.

We are at a distance. The COFFIN (in profile) is being lowered into the ground. We are booming down to FOLLOW the sinking casket (keeping it centered), and as the coffin descends into the earth, so do we. We slowly creep down, losing sight of the cemetery and the mourners. We continue tracking down along the DIRT and the EARTHWORMS and the WEEDS, sinking deeper and deeper into the dark, wet soil. Soon we are swallowed up again in BLACK.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Late afternoon, during the wake, slightly opaque view

SCRIPT.LINE: THE WAKE. Everything seems slightly opaque, as if seen through glass. Glossed over by grief.
People stand uneasily and talk in hushed tones.
STEVE stands in a daze, politely (but absently) accepting condolences.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Same time as wake, Annie in bed facing wall

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie lies in bed, facing the wall. Her back is to us.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Same time as wake, Peter hiding, distorted view of living room

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter stands (hiding?) in the family library, anxiously massaging his CELL PHONE with his thumb. He looks completely battered by trauma and self-loathing.
He observes the wake in the adjacent living room through the distortion of the library’s textured glass door. He watches Steve shake someone’s hand.
A MAN (40s) steps into the library, not expecting to find Peter.
Peter. How are you?
Peter smiles politely, but can’t answer. His eyes look almost deranged.
Can I get you anything?
I’m just gonna use the bathroom.
Okay.
As Peter walks stiffly past, smiling his forced smile, the Man awkwardly adds:
I’m so sorry for your loss.
Thank you.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Continuous, Peter locks door, sounds of wake faintly heard

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter hastily enters the bathroom and LOCKS the door.
He stands frozen for a moment, battling panic. The sounds of the wake persist in the other room.
Peter turns on the SINK to create white noise.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Evening, remaining mourners filtering out, Steve alone

SCRIPT.LINE: The remaining mourners are slowly filtering out. Steve politely ushers them, thanking them for coming.
Soon, everyone’s gone. Steve just stands there, in the middle of the room. Lost.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Moments later, Steve at bathroom door, running sink faintly heard

SCRIPT.LINE: Steve goes to the bathroom door. Tries to open it. It’s LOCKED. The running sink is faintly heard.
Steve pauses, then knocks gently.
Peter?
No answer.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Same time, Peter on tub, sink running, listening to voicemail

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter sits on the edge of the tub. The sink is still running.
He holds his cell to his ear, listening to VOICEMAIL.
You have one saved message. First saved message:
Hi sweetheart, it’s mom. Just calling to make sure that you and Charlie are okay and having a good time at the BBQ. All right. Have lots of fun and be safe. Love you both!
Click.
To listen to this message again, press four.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Moments later, Steve at open door, bed empty, sheets disheveled

SCRIPT.LINE: Steve approaches his bedroom, but STOPS at the open door.
Annie is no longer in bed. The sheets have been dragged halfway off the mattress (presumably by Annie’s feet when she left).

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Moments later, lonely room, Steve enters

SCRIPT.LINE: Charlie’s lonely bedroom. Everything is as it was.
The door OPENS. It’s Steve. He stands at the door, taking the room in. After a moment, he steps inside.
MOMENTS LATER.
Steve sits on Charlie’s bed. He has pulled up Charlie’s DRAWING PAD.
Steve opens the pad. He flips slowly through the pages. He takes care to really look at the drawings. As if appreciating them for the first time.

Steve passes several drawings of severed animal heads (including those of the rabbit, the rat and the cat, which we saw in Charlie’s shoebox). Steve then comes to Charlie’s half-finished drawing of the pigeon head (which now dons a CROWN).
Steve studies it, and then turns the page to discover...a BLANK PAGE. There are no more drawings.
The floodgates open. Steve WEEPS.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, empty room, snowing outside, hallway lights off

SCRIPT.LINE: Charlie’s bedroom is EMPTY again. It’s snowing outside.
The door is open, and the hallway’s lights are off.
Framed by the doorway, Peter walks past, determinedly not looking into the room.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, Peter in bed, alarm clock, treehouse visible

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter enters. Without changing out of his clothes, he climbs into bed. The ALARM CLOCK reads 10:10 PM.
He turns to his side and gazes out the WINDOW. The imposing TREEHOUSE looms just outside. He stares at it.
LATER
Peter rolls huffily from his stomach to his back, unable to sleep. He turns to the ALARM CLOCK. It now reads 1:32 AM.
A beat, and then Peter climbs out of bed, gathers his blanket and pillow, and leaves the room.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Moments later, light snowfall, Peter heading for treehouse

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter, wearing his parka and an Elmer Fudd hat, emerges from the back door of the house. He carries his blanket and pillow through the light snowfall, heading for the TREEHOUSE.
He notes Charlie’s SHOEBOX near the base of the tree (having been dropped from the treehouse?). Flies are audible inside.
Peter grips the tree’s climbing handles and scales the tree.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Continuous, Peter lays out blanket, Annie sleeping in corner

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter climbs in. He lays out his blanket and lies down, positioning his pillow under his head. Now situated, he begins to close his eyes, but before they can shut, he SENSES something behind him. He slowly look back to SEE: ANNIE IS SLEEPING IN THE CORNER, bundled up in blankets.

Startled, Peter STAGGERS out of his blanket, GRABS his things, and rushes frantically out of the treehouse. In his haste, his foot SLIPS OFF one of the wet climbing handles. He falls to land HARD on his back.
In pain, Peter rises and limps back toward the house.
WE SLOWLY DISSOLVE FROM THIS TO...

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, Peter at back of class, distant teacher, blurry flashback

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter sits in the back of class as a teacher drones on at the blackboard. The teacher’s voice is distant and vague, as if heard from UNDER WATER.
Peter’s EYES are busy with nagging, obsessive thoughts. They narrow upward to his right.

We flash briefly to an INSERT of the family car’s REAR VIEW MIRROR (from Peter’s POV) on the night of the accident. The mirror is in focus, but whatever’s in the BACK SEAT (Charlie’s headless body) is blurry and just out of the mirror’s view.
We return to the CLASS. Peter snaps out of his reverie to see BRIDGET looking at him. Their eyes briefly MEET before she quickly turns back to the teacher.
Peter’s eyes HARDEN.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, Annie at mailbox, finding seance brochure

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie draws the MAIL out of the mailbox. Among the letters is a BROCHURE. It reads “Calling All Skeptics!” Below that: “A PUBLIC SEANCE to be conducted by famed spiritual medium, Suzanne Marlowe!”
Annie goes PALE at the sight of this. She looks around, suddenly paranoid - as if nervous that she’s being watched.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, Annie working on hospice miniature, exhausted

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie is at work, trying to make progress on the HOSPICE MINIATURE. Her eyes are numb. She looks exhausted. She turns in her swivel-chair

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, front door unlocking, dog

SCRIPT.LINE: Off-screen, the front door is heard UNLOCKING. Annie looks in the direction of the noise.
The front door opens and Steve enters.
Annie?!
Max runs up to greet Steve, his tail wagging excitedly.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, Annie going to door, closing it

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie goes to the door. Steve is heard scaling the stairs.
Before he can reach the top, Annie silently eases the door shut.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, workshop door, Steve at top of stairs

SCRIPT.LINE: The workshop door quietly CLOSES just before Steve appears at the top of the stairs. He approaches the workshop.
He knocks on the door.
No answer.
He eases the door open. Annie “works” with her back to the door. She’s now wearing HEADPHONES, “listening” to classical music.
Steve smiles sadly and closes the door, leaving Annie to her work.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, kitchen island with mail, trash can

SCRIPT.LINE: Steve enters the kitchen. Mail waits on the kitchen island.
He finds the BROCHURE for the public seance, and DUMPS it in the trash.
In the b.g., Annie CROSSES the doorway. Steve doesn’t see.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Late afternoon, blue family car, Peter on bicycle

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie sits in the blue family car, parked in the driveway. (The green car - the “accident” car - is now permanently gone.) Annie is trying to work up the nerve to start the engine. Then, in the SIDE-VIEW MIRROR, she sees: Peter rides his BICYCLE up the driveway. He arrives at the front porch, but stays on the bike. He doesn’t see Annie.
Annie has TENSED UP. She sits motionless for fear of being seen, eyes LOCKED on Peter. He stands for a long time at the front door, preparing to face his family.
Annie watches as Peter continues to gather himself. He finally takes a decisive breath, gets off the bike, and quietly enters the house.
Annie remains tense. She turns on the car’s IGNITION.

SCENE.LOCATION: Catholic High School Gymnasium Parking Lot
SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Evening, support group gathering, Annie in car

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie idles into the parking lot of the HIGH SCHOOL GYMNASIUM (from earlier). Outside, the same SUPPORT GROUP is gathering.
Annie pulls into a spot. Turns off the ignition. She stares at the gymnasium door. Watches tensely as people solemnly enter. She doesn’t move.

After a long internal debate, Annie finally STARTS the car back up, and begins to drive off. As she approaches the exit, an OLDER WOMAN (late 60s) runs suddenly - and merrily - into the HEADLIGHTS, flagging Annie down. Annie BRAKES.
The woman circles over to Annie’s window. Annie hesitantly rolls it down.
Hi! Hello. Sorry to chase you down. Were you not coming in?
I, no, I just - forgot something.
Okay, sorry, I just - I recognized you from a few months ago. You were here because your mother?
Oh...
I feel crazy now. Sorry! I’m Joan.
Hi.
Are you doing any better?
What?
With your mother...?
What? No. That’s not... My daughter was killed.
Oh. My God. I’m so, so sorry.
Brief, heavy silence. Joan stammeringly offers:
Would you like to come in with me? Or we can even just get a coffee. There’s a place down the street.
I’m sorry. Really. Thank you. I really did forget something.
Joan bluntly offers:
My son died.
Oh...! I’m so sorry.
Joan smiles tightly, heartbroken.
How old was yours?
Annie looks like she’s being held hostage.
Fourteen.
Oh God, that’s awful! My son and my grandson drowned. Four months ago. The little one was seven.
Oh my God.
I’ve been coming here for a month now and it has helped. I just wanted to say. It has. It doesn’t make it easier - obviously. But sometimes it just, makes it less lonely.
Okay...
And I’m gonna embarrass myself now, but if you ever need someone to talk to...
Joan writes her PHONE NUMBER onto a piece of paper.
’Cause we all do.
She hands Annie the phone number.
Just if you need it.
Okay. Thank you. Really.
Annie is moved, despite her discomfort. Joan walks off, giving Annie a warm little wave.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, Annie removing snow boots

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie lumbers in. She pulls off her snow boots.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, Steve asleep in armchair, muted TV glow

SCRIPT.LINE: Steve is asleep in an armchair, bathed in the dim glow of the muted TV. Annie appears in the doorway.
Hey.
Oh! Hey.
I’m going to bed.
Where were you?
At the movies. I’m going to bed.
I’ll come with you.
...Okay.
Annie leaves the doorway.
And can you please let me know when you’re going to the movies? I was worried.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, couple in bed, tense atmosphere

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie and Steve are in bed. Annie’s back is to Steve. Neither is asleep.
Steve gently SNUGGLES UP to Annie, but she is like stone. He self-consciously touches her hip. She recoils.
Steve backs off. There is a long moment of tension, and then Annie RISES from bed.
I’m gonna be right back.
She gathers a blanket, which is bundled on the room’s armchair.
You’re not coming right back. You’re taking the blanket.
I can’t sleep.
Annie: it’s freezing outside.
The heater’s up there.
Steve wants to fight this, but Annie is clearly anxious to avoid a conversation.
...Okay.
Is that okay?
Yeah. Fine. Come back if you get cold.
I just need to sleep.
Annie leaves.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, ominous wide shot, Annie asleep, bright orange heaters

SCRIPT.LINE: We push in on an ominous WIDE of Annie lying asleep in Charlie’s treehouse. Two LARGE HEATERS have been set up on either side of her. They burn a BRIGHT ORANGE.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, Peter awake in bed, orange glow from outside, dark corner

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter lies in bed, awake. Outside his window, Charlie’s treehouse emits an orange glow.
A CLICKING SOUND (like Charlie’s tongue-clicking) is suddenly heard in the room. Peter FREEZES, now listening for it. After a moment, there’s another CLICK.
Peter BOLTS up in bed. His eyes frenziedly scan the room. He fixes on a DARK CORNER. A HOODIE SWEATSHIRT hangs on the wall, and for a brief moment, it looks almost like a standing person.
Peter continues listening intently for another click... Silence. It has stopped.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Beautiful day, Annie intently working on replica bedroom, paint spill

SCRIPT.LINE: Outside, a beautiful day.

Inside, Annie is hard at work. Her eyes are intense - furious even - as she carefully works on the replica of Charlie’s bedroom. She scratches a tiny replica of the word-carving she saw earlier (”Satony”) into the wall behind the bed. As she does this, her attention is drawn to a looming POST-IT NOTE, which reads: Call gallery about extending?
Annie disregards this. She goes for a new bottle of paint, but as she reaches, an open paint bottle is KNOCKED over.
Shit.
It tipped over near Annie’s extending hand, but it didn’t look like Annie actually touched it.
Annie grabs paper towels and quickly mops up the mess. She pulls a few drenched items out of the widening paint puddle.
Among them: JOAN’S PHONE NUMBER. She looks at it.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, students in hallway, Peter walking

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter walks absent-mindedly down the hall. THREE STONER BOYS (including Brendan) are walking toward him, huddled and giggling. They notice Peter.
Yo, Pete.
Hey.
You wanna join us for a walk?
On “walk,” he mimes pinching a joint with his thumb and forefinger.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, Peter and stoners under bleachers, passing pipe

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter sits under the BLEACHERS with the three stoners. They pass around a PIPE packed with weed. Brendan takes a hit.
Am I the only one who’s Facebook friends with Becky?
Brendan passes the pipe to Peter.
You’re friends with Be

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Messy room, day, smoking pot

SCRIPT.LINE: Facebook friends, bitch! Oh my God, her statuses...
Oh my God, dude, I know.
Every ten seconds!
Peter LIGHTS the bowl and takes a reluctant hit.
“I’m going to the bathroom now.” 5:45. “Just got back from the bathroom!” 5:46.
Peter COUGHS OUT a lungful of pot smoke. He immediately looks regretful.
What about Brian with his girlfriend?
Stoner #2 nods his head, choking on laughter. Peter’s eyes are wide with a burgeoning panic. He does not look well.
Ha! His “princess”?!
“Going to pick up my princess from the airport!” “Eating cous-cous with my princess!”
Peter looks like he’s starting to have an ATTACK. The Stoners are oblivious.
Who’s his girlfriend?
Some fuckin’ stupid college chick.
What the fuck?! I want some stupid college princess chick.
Stoner #2 notices that Peter is freaking out.
Dude. Are you okay?
I feel like I can’t breathe.
What?
I feel like I’m having a reaction.
No, man, don’t freak out. You just smoked too much.
No, I think I need a doctor. My tongue is getting bigger.
Peter is crying now.
Should we take you to the nurse??
I dunno.
Look, dude: you’re breathing. See? You’re just really high.
Peter is trying to calm down.
See? You’re okay. You just got too high. You’re okay, dude. You’re breathing.
Stoner #2 and Stoner #3 exchange “holy shit” looks.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, urban street, busy

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie walks down an urban street, looking for an address. She pinches the paper with Joan’s number. On its other side is an ADDRESS in Annie’s handwriting.
Annie finds the address. A large, red-brick APARTMENT BUILDING.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, well-lit apartment hallway

SCRIPT.LINE: The elevator opens, depositing Annie onto the THIRD FLOOR.
Annie proceeds down the well-lit hall, arriving at APARTMENT 316. She knocks.
While waiting, Annie looks down. She’s standing on a HAND-MADE WELCOME MAT. The word “JOANIE” has been embroidered into it.
After a moment, the door is opened by JOAN.
Annie! You came!
It’s a little earlier than we said.
Ah, you’re perfect. Come in.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, cheerfully decorated, homey colors

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie follows Joan in. Joan closes the door behind them. The apartment is cheerfully decorated in bright, homey colors.
Joan rushes off to the KITCHEN, where a TEA KETTLE is whistling. Annie stays by the door.
Your welcome mat...
Oh - it’s cute, right?
Joan pulls the kettle off the stove and pours two cups.
My mother used to embroider ones just like that.
Oh really? How funny!
Joan sets the tea on the KITCHEN table.
Please. Sit.

MINUTES LATER Joan and Annie sit at the table, nursing their tea. The conversation has become very heavy, and the spotlight is currently on a very fragile Annie. She speaks steadily, in fragments, as if to hold herself together. Her eyes are fixed on the floor.
He left her in the back seat. Went straight to bed.
Joan nods sympathetically. Her eyes locked attentively on Annie.

And then I wake up. Went to my workshop. Needed some supplies. I go down to the car. Step inside. First the smell of something wrong. Then the - body. Slumped. Covered in black, blood, like tar... And her head wasn’t there, so I couldn’t see her face. But they were her clothes. And her hands... her fingernails...
Joan is pale as she listens. Annie is trembling, locked on the memory.
Joan gently lays her hand over Annie’s. Beat.

When they dragged up my son and grandson, they needed me to identify the bodies. But they didn’t warn me what bodies look like after they’ve been in the ocean. You can probably imagine - they swell up, get distended, turn grey. I didn’t know that. My son’s eyes were eaten out of his head by fish. And my grandson’s face - like a balloon.
Annie is looking up at Joan now. They share in this. The grisly details are somehow (in their morbid way) comforting.
Breaking the spell, Annie pulls a PILL from her purse. She downs it with a gulp of TEA. She catches something on her tongue, and pulls a BLACK HERB from her mouth. She pays it no mind.
I can sometimes swear I feel them in the room... Do you ever have that?
...Small moments maybe.
This hangs for a moment.
How’s your relationship with your son?
...Peter?
Joan brightens: “That’s his name?” Annie thinks about Joan’s question.
Oh God...
Her face DARKENS and she chuckles. She brushes it off, but then PAUSES. She decides to actually answer.

I sleepwalk. I haven't in a long time, but two years ago I woke up - and I really don’t remember this because I was asleep - but I woke up standing next to Peter and Charlie’s bed (when they shared a room), and they were completely covered in paint thinner... And so was I. From head to toe... And I was standing there, and I was holding a box of matches. And I woke myself up by striking one. Which also woke up Peter. And he started screaming. And I immediately put out the match, immediately, but my husband came in... and I was just as shocked as he was, but I was the one with the matches.
Joan is listening with no judgment. Annie, frustrated by the memory, takes a deep breath.

And it was impossible to convince them that it was just sleepwalking - which of course it was - but the timing was awful, Peter and I had already fallen into this stupid quarrelling phase - arguing forever about nothing - such frivolous things - but that’s when the incident happened, so...! Over time, everyone affected casualness, “moving on.” But they never forgot and Peter’s always held it against me and there's nothing I can say and there’s nothing I can do because it happened. While I was asleep.
Did your daughter hold it against you?
Oh, she was off in the clouds somewhere. Probably didn’t even notice.
Beat.
It’s impossible being a mother.
Annie looks at Joan. “Yes it is.”

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, modern kitchen, chopping carrots

SCRIPT.LINE: Steve is chopping carrots at the kitchen island. Peter is heard ENTERING in the foyer.
Hey, that was fast. Did you bike all the way here?
My friend dropped me.
Oh - you should’ve invited him in.
But Peter’s already going for the stairs. Steve tries to catch up with him.
Did you remember to sign up for that SAT prep course?
Peter has made it to the top of stairs. Hiding his wrought face:
I will tomorrow.
You need to, Peter! That’s coming up!

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, messy teenager's room

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter lies in bed, on his side. He looks ready to burst back into tears.
Steve knocks on the door. Pokes his head in.
Peter?
Peter turns to him, stifling tears.
Are you okay?
Are you?
Pause.
Is there anything we can talk about, Peter?
Like what?
Like anything. What’s going on? What are you feeling?
What are you feeling?
I’m worried about you.
Peter stares at Steve, eyes wide. Unable to communicate.
It doesn’t have to be with me, either. Maybe you’d like to talk with somebody else...
About what?
About everything. You’re going through a lot, Peter.
So are you!
Well - we all are. I think we could all use someone to talk to.
So why aren’t you, then?
I probably will. I probably need to.
A long, fraught pause.
You don’t have to choose

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior of a family home, a bit somber, late afternoon

SCRIPT.LINE: now. I’m just letting you know that it’s there.
You could even see one of the guys in my building. I know a few guys.
...And you think I need to go?
Well, that’s for you to say. I can’t tell you your experience.
Peter suddenly deflates. Not the answer he needed. He chills over.
Maybe later.
...Okay. Let me know.
Okay.
Steve nods for a long time. Trying to think of anything else.
All right. Dinner in a bit.
Steve smiles sensitively. Too sensitive. He leaves.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, cluttered workshop, with miniature models and tools, dim lighting

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie is at work. Behind her, the door opens and Steve enters. He approaches to see...

Annie is working on a new piece: a NEW MINIATURE of the HIGHWAY of Charlie’s accident, including the TELEPHONE POLE that took her head. This also features a tiny figurine of Charlie’s decapitated head and a figurine of Peter in the family car.
Oh Jesus... Are you planning on letting him see that?
Who?
How do you think Peter’s gonna feel about that?
What? It’s not about him.
Oh no?
...It’s an objective view of the accident!
Steve just eyes her.
Okay, so what is it, then?
It’s cruel, Annie. And unforgiving...
Oh my God!
And useless.
What do you think I’m trying to say with this?! You think I’d ever want to hurt my own son?! Are you crazy?!
Steve almost responds, but bites his tongue.
Oh Jesus you’re sanctimonious. I get it: you’re a good father, you’re a good husband - get off the stage.
Steve boils.
Are you coming to dinner?
I’m making dinner!
I made dinner! I’m GETTING you for dinner! Come down or stay here, I don’t give a shit.
On “give”, he SLAMS the door behind him.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, dinner table set for three, tense atmosphere, unswallowed pill by a glass

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie, Steve and Peter sit at the dinner table. A fourth chair divides Annie and Peter. Annie is fuming from her last interaction with Steve. Beside her glass: an unswallowed pill.
This is really good, dad.
Annie balks to herself. Peter tenses.
Thanks buddy.
Annie mouths the word “buddy” to herself, incredulous. Peter catches this.
You okay, mom?
What?
Is there something on your mind?
Annie can’t believe this.
Is there something on your mind?
It just looks like you might want to say something.
Peter...
Like what? Why would I want to say something? So I can watch you can roll your eyes at me?
I have never rolled my eyes to. You get the point across.
Oh sweetie - you don’t have at you.
Okay. So say what you wanna say, then.
Peter--
I don’t want to say anything. I’ve tried saying things.
So try again. Release yourself.
Release you, you mean!
So fine, so release me! What do you wanna say? Fuckin’ say it!
Annie explodes out of her seat.

Don't you swear at me - you little shit! You don’t EVER raise your voice at me! I'm your Mother, you understand? I've given everything to you! All I ever DO is worry and slave and defend you, and all I get back is that fucking face on your face! So full of disdain and resentment and always so annoyed. Well, now your sister’s dead! And I know you miss her and I know it was an “accident” and I know you're in pain - and I wish I could take it all away! I wish I could shield you from the knowledge that you did what you did - but your sister is dead. She's gone forever. And what a waste. If it could’ve maybe brought us together - something! - if you could have just said “I’m sorry” or faced up to what happened: maybe then we could do something with this! But you can’t take responsibility for anything, so now I can’t accept. And I can’t forgive. Because nobody admits what they’ve done!
She sits down. A heavy silence.
Peter is looking away, fighting tears. But then, after a long silence...
And what about you, mom? I didn’t want to take her...and she didn’t want to go... So why was she there?
Annie looks at him. Incredulous. She is boiling with rage, but...this has also hit her somewhere deep. She’s desperately avoided facing this question since the accident.
Okay, we’re stopping this.
He looks at Annie, who looks like she’s about to lose her mind.
We’re stopping this right now.
Annie glowers at him. Adversarial. She finally relents.
Fine.
She tensely RISES hesitates, but then hesitates, about to say something else. But then:
Fine.
She leaves.
Steve turns to Peter: he’s doing everything in his power to keep from exploding into tears. Steve looks powerless to help.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, bedroom, tense atmosphere, dimly lit

SCRIPT.LINE: Steve enters the bedroom, furious. Annie is sitting on the bed, a hardness in her eyes.
What the hell are you doing?
What am I doing?!
Try to stop and see what’s happening, Annie. For one second. Try to see where this could go. It’s not the right choice.
These are your choices, too! You choose to not see how he is. How cold he is with me. How dimissive.
So we’ll deal with that! We can go to family therapy, whatever - but don’t make it about Charlie!
Oh, family therapy! Right!
So what, then? We just chalk it up to an act of God?
Yes.
He just left her in the car! Went straight to bed! Not a word!
You can’t even imagine he was in shock?
He left us to be in shock, too!
There was no way around that. You need to stop this. If he had warned us, we still would have run out there to find her in the same way.
And it wasn’t a fucking BBQ either. He lied to us, through his teeth. He took her to some sleazy high school house party!
You knew it wasn’t a BBQ!
He just left her head in the road and kept driving. He went to sleep!
Goddamn it -- He was in shock. He’s still in shock.
He looks pretty gathered to me.
Gathered?!
You’re holding yourself together awfully well, too!
Excuse me? And what the hell does that mean? Someone has to keep things from unraveling completely, Annie.
It HAS unraveled completely!
Silence. Steve is frozen.
...Don’t worry. I blame myself, too.
That’s worthless.
I’m the one who made her go to the party.
Oh, stop it!
No! Don’t you dare! He’s right! I made Peter take her! She begged me not to go!
I was happy she was going! Be around other kids instead of that fuckin’ treehouse for a change! I would have pushed her if you hadn't!
But you didn’t push her. I did.
...We have no control over anything, Annie. The ceiling could collapse on us right now and who would we blame?
Brief pause.
You don’t understand anything, do you?

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, teenager's bedroom, dimly lit, Peter lying in bed staring out the window

SCRIPT.LINE: Peter boils in bed, staring out the window.
A gentle knock at the door. It cracks open and Steve sticks his head in.
Goodnight, Petey.
Peter looks at Steve.
Do you blame me, too?
Goddamn it -
Steve opens the door all the way.
- of course not. No one blames you.
Steve approaches Peter.
I don’t for one second imagine that you’re not going through the exact same thing we are.
Mom doesn’t think so.
Stop it with mom. She’s blaming everyone. It’s part of grieving. She blames herself.
Peter has started to cry.
She wasn’t driving the car.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dimly lit, somber, emotional atmosphere

SCRIPT.LINE: She could have. Anyone could have.
I didn’t even care about her...! That’s how it happened...!
Steve is momentarily overwhelmed.
You love your sister.
I should be dead. At least she could draw. She made things. I don’t do anything.
Yes you do. Don’t ever say that.
I’m nothing. I do nothing.
Steve, looking helpless, rests his hand on Peter’s head. Peter WEEPS. Steve is also crying now.
I’m sorry!
Shhh! I’m sorry.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, dark, sounds muffled, deep sadness

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie lies on the bed, her back to us. We hear Peter’s weeping, muffled through the walls. We then hear:
I’m sorry.
Annie’s back begins to rise and fall in a fit of sobs.
FADE TO BLACK

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, messy workshop, unfinished miniatures, motivational note

SCRIPT.LINE: CLOSE-UP of Annie’s face. Lethargic. She’s lost a few pounds since we last saw her, and is wearing an old T-shirt and pajama bottoms.
She stares at her unfinished miniatures. Her eyes then drift to a Post-It note above her desk. It reads “KEEP WORKING!”

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, bright, aisles of art supplies, miniatures section

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie pushes a cart down an aisle of miniature building materials. She looks farther down the aisle, and suddenly STOPS, having noticed...
JOAN is pushing a cart toward Annie. She hasn’t yet noticed Annie. She wears an ECSTATIC SMILE as she giddily scans the chalk section.
Confused by Joan’s demeanor (and her presence), Annie warily begins to push her cart toward her.
Joan?
Joan looks up to see Annie.
Oh my -- Annie?!
Joan circles the carts to give Annie a big, warm, very sustained HUG.
Are you okay?
Oh Annie. Yes. I’m really good. I’m really really...
Annie nods, forcing a smile. She looks concerned for Joan’s sanity.
Something happened, Annie. I feel completely - turned around.
What happened?
I don’t know if I should even say!
What do you mean?
You’re gonna think I’m crazy!
Not at all...!
I... Oh God. I... ...met a spiritual medium.
Annie affects a patronizing “Oh Wow” expression.

They were performing an open seance -- and I know: I know what you’re thinking, but they asked me to attend. They were bringing in skeptics and scientists so they wouldn’t be accused of fraud. But I went, fully skeptical, and what I experienced there was truly...
Joan tries to think of a suitably ecstatic adjective.
An “open seance”?

They brought back the spirit of a man from the 19th century! And not like as a smoke and mirrors thing. The man next to me was a deadly cynical neurologist, and he looked permanently changed by the end of it.
Annie makes another “wow” face.

And I do know what you’re thinking, Annie - of course - but I approached the medium and I asked her about my son and grandson, and she came to my apartment and she ended up performing a, uh - well - she...conjured my grandson!
Annie, still forcing a smile, now looks frightened.
I know what you’re smiling at. I wouldn’t believe it myself. I didn’t! But I heard his voice, I felt him in the room. It’s real.
Annie’s warped smile is plastered appeasingly to her face.
What are you doing right now?
I’m just - here, shopping.
You wanna come over?
Annie doesn’t know what to say.
I really think you should. Please. It would be everything if you came.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, dark interior, blacked-out window, mystical setup

SCRIPT.LINE: The front door opens and Joan enters, followed uneasily by Annie. Joan smiles widely.
Hello!
This “hello” was seemingly directed at the room in general.
Joan hustles to the KITCHEN. She takes SWEETGRASS and smears it across the surface of the kitchen table. Also on the table is an UPTURNED DRINKING GLASS.
This is part of it.
